Rudiger took his time settling into life in England, but adapted and has become a brilliant stalwart of the Chelsea back-line. His performance in the FA Cup final win over Manchester United was immense. He’s not quite as aggressive a defender as Sokratis, attempting 1.8 tackles per-90 minutes in the Premier League this season compared to the Greek’s 2.8 in the Bundesliga.

Sokratis is a superb tackler, of his 2.8 attempted tackles he won an incredible 89% of them, up on Rudiger’s 67% success rate. Rudiger is more timely with interceptions, however, and they both made 3.9 clearances last season. The thing here is not whether Sokratis is better than Rudiger, they’re about the same, it’s just Sokratis’ style of play isn’t quite as complimentary to Arsenal’s other defenders as Rudiger’s ability to play clean-up would be.

Verdict: draw (with style points to Rudiger)

Liverpool paid a world-record £75m for Virgil Van Dijk in January 2018 and it’s only been five months but that looks like money well spent so far. The Dutch defender is a colossal presence at the heart of the Liverpool defence, organising them into a solid defensive unit that can actually withstand pressure from the opponents (as long as their goalkeeper doesn’t… you know what it’s to soon).

When compared to Sokratis he certainly doesn’t tackle as much, but Van Dijk has thus far not missed a tackle in his half-season at Anfield. Attempting 1.1 per-90 and winning 1.1 per-90. Again he makes more interceptions and protects his side with an enormous 5.6 clearances per-90. Van Dijk is a colossus and has transformed Liverpool in a way it’s hard to see an aggressive defender like Sokratis managing to do for Arsenal; remember the Reds reached the Champions League final with a teenage midfielder at right-back and calamity Dejan Lovren in the middle.

Verdict: Van Dijk

Mauricio Pochettino’s men are blessed with two great Belgian centre-backs, and whilst Toby Alderweireld has spent most of this season injured or being frozen out by Pochettino, Jan Vertonghen has stepped up and has been perhaps been the finest defender in the Premier League over the whole season.

Vertonghen is a rugged tackler, attempting 2.1 tackles per-90 and winning 1.8; that’s an 86% success rate which is around the same level as Sokratis. Both men aren’t shy of putting in challenges and have the capability to do so, but Vertonghen is a more accomplished interceptor. Able to step up and cut off attacks before tackles are needed, winning 1.7 per-90 to Sokratis’ 1.1.

Vertonghen has also made 4.8 clearances compared to Sokratis’ 3.9 – almost an entire extra clearance per-90 as he made sure the ball was removed from danger areas posthaste. Sokratis is good but there’s no contest here, Spurs’ Belgian is not quite as aggressive but (once Alderweireld departs) will remain the best defender in North London.

Verdict: Vertonghen

Eric Bailly was a sensation for Manchester United last season and looked to be the latest in a long line of great Mourinho defenders. This season, however, he’s been beset by injury and then bizarre non-selection by Mourinho for reasons which read like a headline at The Onion. Still, he’s logged 1000 minutes in the Premier League so how does he compare?

In terms of tackling, Bailly attempts as many as Sokratis wins and manages to win only 1.5 per-90. He’s not much of a tackler and the Greek has the advantage in those kind of duels. However Bailly is possibly the most aggressive centre-back in the league, not in terms of violence, but the way he pushes up to pick passes off.

Bailly has made 2.3 interceptions per-90; comfortably more than any of the centre-backs on this list and way more than Sokratis’ 1.1 He’s also thumped away 5 clearances per-90, again more than the Greek. He may have barely been playing because of his manager’s mania, but Eric B is President, Sokratis is his defeated Primary opponent.

Verdict: Bailly

Manchester City’s magnificent title win was based on their midfield and attack. Their defence contributed, obviously, but if there was a “weak area” it was the centre-backs. But one thing is for sure, Pep Guardiola is finally getting the best out of Nico Otamendi – but just how good is Nico Otamendi’s best? After all until John Stones fell away around mid-season, Otamendi wasn’t City’s best centre-back.

The Argentine attempts 2.9 tackles per-90 but only wins 2.1 – that 72% success rate is still impressive, but can’t touch Sokratis’ 89%. He’s made 1.5 interceptions compared to Sokratis’ 1.1, but he’s only got 3.7 clearances to the Greek’s 3.9 Stylistically, the two are simlar; burly defenders who love duels and enjoy getting physical with opponents. Both could benefit from a more calm partner, someone who can play on the back foot more as they maraud around.

Ultimately, you’d have to give Sokratis the edge here because both defenders base much of their game on tackling and Sokratis is much more efficient at it than Otamendi. As a further tie-breaker, whilst Otamendi wins just 54% of his 4.5 aerial duels per-90, Sokratis wins 66% of his 4.7 – again; they do much of the same stuff, Sokratis just does it better.

Verdict: Sokratis
